page.title: 14ST. ANDREWS CHURCH
page.content: The oldest building in Tangmere village, found in the extreme south-west of the village and first mentioned in the Domesday Book, is St. Andrews Church. It was probably first built in Saxon days, but the present Church was constructed in the early 12th century. St. Andrews has one of the oldest fonts in Sussex, tub shaped and made of stone. The bell-cote and the spire were added in the 13th century. In 1985 it remains attractive and well cared for, the graveyard often attracts interest as there are several graves of both German and British Airmen alongside old village names such as Bayley and Osborn. The Vicar who lives in Boxgrove has dual responsibility for both parishes. He spends Thursday in the village spending time at the School and with the parishoners.
